By @CronistaOscar: “Of the more than 240,000 unaccompanied minors detained at the border since 2012, only 56 were suspected of having connections to MS-13 when they arrived. If they made those connections after entering the US, the US is to blame.” https://t.co/3RTCnE1cqN

Also the fact that Trump is still raging about the caravan despite the fact that it’s already been stopped by Mexican authorities 1500 miles from US border underscores degree to which US had outsourced border enforcement to Mexico, something Trump is seemingly unaware of.

Bannon may be gone, but the Big Caravan is a confirmation of his worldview taken from Camp of the Saints, in which immigration is an organized conspiracy designed to undermine the West, a prophesy that still shapes White House immigration and refugee policy.

This seems bizarre without understanding the Trump admin’s view of immigration in apocalyptic, clash-of-civilization terms rather than the produce of individual decisions motivated by economic or security concerns. https://t.co/TyM1RdsRf4

Pols like Scott Walker forget one of the main selling points of collective bargaining laws was labor peace, i.e. disciplining militancy. Lack of CB rights makes a workforce more, not less prone to strike. https://t.co/NGjYGFCxMU

tl;dr: All politics is identity politics.
- independent ≠ centrist or “moderate.”
- there are no fundamental differences on the whole between Clinton and Sanders voters.
- Trump represents the heart of the Republican Party much more than do the Koch brothers. There are no real libertarians outside of a handful of rich donors and their think tanks.
- Republicans are mostly ok with government regulation, expanding health care and entitlements.
- Republicans care way more about cultural issues than economic ones, and way more about cultural issues than Dems.
- Republicans are not abandoning the party over Trump, and Trump voters are not abandoning him.
All of the findings here are worth highlighting. Not necessarily surprising to political scientists, though perhaps contrary to conventional wisdom: https://t.co/vgumr6AiDm

So in Korean, being fat isn’t a characteristic, it’s an activity: you walk around all day being fat. And thus it’s totally valid for strangers to have opinions and advice and comment on what you are doing.

In the Korean language, a lot of adjectives are verbs. The way you say someone is fat is “doong-doong hae” (or “doong-doong hamnida” if you are being polite) which literally translates as “doing fat.” In Spanish it would be like saying “hacer gordo.”
I have a linguistic theory about why Koreans, especially older Koreans, love talking about fat people and telling people they are fat.

@aspaglayan I don’t read it as bad news for unions. Unions sell to (prospective) members argument that unionization = higher salaries. This is true even if it’s not causal. But strikes are almost never about salaries. See WV where teachers rejected gov’s 1st offer that included major raises.
